column5: What is the water clarity like on the Indian lake chain? I was up at Cliff Lake about 20 miles north of Vbay and it was crystal clear. I am hoping to find something with a little more tanin to the water.
Indian Lake chain is fairly clear but not like cliff lake.
Paradise Cove in Minaki is a great place. Drive right to your cabin, access to a ton of amazing water (Winnipeg River system). And Duane is a super great guy.https://paradisecoveminaki.com

Tops on my list would be Five Lakes Lodge. Great fishing for Walleye and good size Northern. Ian runs a great camp and checks in with everyone ensuring they are all enjoying the trip and catching fish. Cabins, boats and grounds all kept clean. Equipment is always functioning as it should. Walleye numbers were excellent that past 2 Aug trips but the June trips have produced the larger fish for us. A ton of solid 15-16" fish.Second on the list would be Woman River Camp. Same as above with regards to cabins, boats, grounds and management. Paul runs a nice camp and we caught plenty of fish. Bonus is the portage lakes and adds a little adventure.Third on the list would probably be Thaddeus Lake Lodge. Marty runs a nice camp and good fishery. Better chance at bigger Walleye but not an overall numbers kind of place. Also Northern sizes not really there but good numbers of small/medium fish. Also holds Smallmouth if that is your thing. The transit to Ord/Moose gets you to the better numbers of fish but can also be challenging depending on water levels through the channel.Fourth on the list would be Clark's on Cedar Lake. Great cabins, especially if you get the deluxe units. If taking a family with younger kids this is a great spot. Nice boats and accommodations but struggled for fish and early season when we were there was a longer boat ride each day getting to the far end of the lake system.
New owners taking over April 2023. Gonna miss Kathy and Blair.

[QUOTE=Eckohlt;6681928]Good morning from Latreille Lake Lodge Rod.Going to fish that hump this morning again for a while.Cool and foggy this morning but calm and sunny.Fire started in lodge and in no rush.Breakfast first.Dont have to worry about anybody getting to that spot here.lol.
[QUOTE=prov1800;6681946]Looks like a awesome morn there,calm,you can sit on that hump right on top of them n start reef'n them in.
[QUOTE=Eckohlt;6681972]Everyone here in slow mode every morning.lol.Kinda nice.Fish aren't going anywhere.
[QUOTE=prov1800;6681974]Kinda like a nursing home there takes awhile to get jumped started for the day lol,I would like that calm water for a whole week starting sept 24,but that ain't gonna happen.

Echo and Prov1800- maybe you guys should just pick up the phone and talk- this was a thread on Drive To camps. As to the original post- I'm not sure if he was asking only about housekeeping places. If so, our favorite in terms of fish catching is Basket Lake. Our favorite overall experience is Temple Bay (we've only been there in September)- they offer housekeeping and American.

They do that with about 80% of the threads on this page. Need a echo...prov....clarks advertisement board. . I have fished basket before.....The North's family still own it? We had to bring own boats or motors....all they supplied was little 16 foot boats with no motors long ago? Maybe a different basket lake? The fishing was good there though.

ðŸ˜€ Yep, that's the same Basket Lake, still owned by the North family. You're right about the boats, I forgot they don't provide any now - byob and beer. Strict conservation rules too- but good fishing.
Press Lake CampAustin's Wilderness Fishing Lodge
Tinker's Nestorfalls
I'll drive-into Donnellys Minnataki Camp any day, on the Minnataki Lake system.

Check out Snake Falls Camp on Pakwash. Great owners, great cabins, located at the mouth of a river, lake is not too big but not too small. All housekeeping plan cabins that are located across their own bridge so it feels like its more remote - It's a drive to but Rob and Mike will bring your items across the bridge right to your door.. And priced very fairly in my opinion. It doesn't fish like a fly in lake with Walleyes on every cast no matter where you go, but it's easy to find plenty of great fishing spots that they will put you on. Without travelling far by boat. The Walleyes, Northerns, Perch, and Smallmouth are great. But no Muskies or Lake Trout.. Just another option for you..

While I want to agree with Rich, Savant is not a drive to in the purest sense either since they take you in and out with an atv or brute van. Leaving in a week so look for a report! My choice to answer this inquiry would be Woman River Camp. Good fishing, a lot of water, quality free portages, reasonable prices, nice cabins and great hosts guarantee a quality experience. Fish On! Hooks

Of the camps I've stayed over the years I've always enjoyed Onaway on Lac Seul. The owner and I have our differences, but Id also give Vermillion Bay Lodge kudos'. I haven't been there in years, but from what I remember he's got a nice camp, cabins, location on the water, services, etc... I always wanted to try Lac Seul Lodge outpost. Ive driven by the outpost but never stayed. Looks great!
Cool and windy so time for a fire in Lodge.

Several years ago I arranged with Gord for a tour of his VBL after returning from a fly-out with Wilderness Air. Gord doesn't need a shout-out from me, but he does have a nice HK camp. What you see in his pics is what you get flowers too. Vermillion Bay is farther than I generally drive anymore. But if a HK camp on that part of Eagle Lake was a destination for me I'd give VBL a serious look.
Ash Rapids Lodge LOTW ON. Boat in, good boat launch off HWY 1. Great fishing, cool place, awesome people own the place.

Prov1800's picture reminds me of another great trip, technically not a "drive-to" but "drive-to, boat-in": Lac Seul Outposts. One cold and wet day in September we returned from a day of fishing to a warm cabin where they had already started a fire for us. Lac Seul Outposts is on the list of places I'd return to.
Early winter??seems alittle early for a fire.

[QUOTE=Eckohlt;6681804]Early winter??seems alittle early for a fire.Pretty cool in Lodge today 11c up here at Latreille Lodge this morning.Gloomy and 25km winds.Got out fishing late in afternoon when it calmed down.Ran over a hump and stopped and fished and was great action.Some bigger fish.Will work it some more tomorrow.Great sunset tonight.

[QUOTE=prov1800;6681880]I better get the auger fired up john,be in your neck of the woods before you know it,I hope heaven looks like that pic on the right,the picture on the left,well alls I can say is that's a pretty fish lol
John thought you were out scouting for moose and winging lures for gators???

Technically not a drive to because the last leg is a boat in, Lady Evelyn Lake in Northern Ontario served us well for three trips. We drive from Southeast Pa and spend as much time on our drive as we are comfortable with. We meet the boat that takes us to the lodge in the morning. It's quite an adventure if you've never done it before. The advantage of this trip is that you are not pulling a boat and usually six guys and their gear can travel together in a large SUV or Van. With the price of gas this has become an important consideration. The Lodges we use are full service. Meals, Breakfast, packed Lunch and dinner are provided as are great boats (16 footers), with live wells, (I hate to string fish). Gas, bait, and boat cleanup are part of the deal. I wouldn't try to say that the experience rivals a fly in to the wilderness but the lake is big enough to get into that environment. My guys are in their seventies, I'm the oldest, this is the best trip for us going forward. Big walleye are available on this lake and I've caught my share of them. Lots of drive too's out there. Good Luck.
Moosehorn Lodge or Red Pine Lodge both in Sioux Lookout.
From an east ender, O'Sullivans Rainbow on O'Sullivan Lake and Happy Day Lodge on Lake Windermere.
Wildewood on Savant gets my vote.
My vote is for Crawford's Camp in Sioux Narrows, Matt and his wife do a great job !!
Vic&Dots Nestorfalls

Up at Latreille Lake.Got here Sunday.Flew in the Caravan so was 40 minute flight in which was beautifull..Old owners are still here and had 4 other fisherman on the flight in.Have seen lots of walleye but no moose yet.Fishing has been very steady and since its kinda a holiday only fishing couple of hrs in morning and afternoon.Its a American plan with a breakfast and come in for lunch and then a supper.So not fishing all day.Yesterday caught 50 walleye in a couple of hours.Getting spoiled.weather has been up and down and fairly windy but easy to find fishable waters.Fishing has been solid so far.Definatly a great Lodge to stay at.Have found some 18" walleye but so far we get into a lot of 13-16".Today windy but will go a bit farther.Hard to fish wind in a 14 ft boat.There are camp spots but so far wife and I are doing good finding some different spots.Will see how it goes today as it's windy.
Might mention that we have caught a number of blue walleye.
Looks pretty peaceful out there!

Mike Borger had a list of his top 3 fly in spots. Would love to hear the top 5 drive too camps. We can base it on quality of walleye fishing. Price---maybe under 1,000????? Folks that do their own cooking and do not need a meal plan? Cabins? Location? Would love to hear what you all think. For me...just need a decent cabin, i cook myself, need a decent boat and amazing walleye fishing. I do not care for huge lakes like lac seul or eagle....just my preference is all.

I like the old post lodge. A little pricey but the fishing is very good. takes some time to learn the lake with all of the structure and size of the lake. lots of prop busting structure is the downside
I have heard great things about that lodge and lake. Watched a few Linder shows when they were there.

Although I've never been to Old Post, I'll second Bigtaproot's suggestion of Lake St. Joseph for great walleye fishing. For under $1,000 you'd have to try Camp Lake St. Joseph. It is a big lake, however, and Old Post and Camp Lake St. Joseph are a ways from the areas that are fished the most. Camp Lake St. Joseph is less expensive but more rustic. The Winoga Lodge cabin is excellent and in the middle of great fishing, but it's more than $1,000. It's still a big lake, but at the Winoga cabin you're only fishing 5-10 minutes away.

Been to old post n camp st joe many times,that's white knuckle driving to get down n past Carling island (think I got that right ),there's also a safe cabin down there not sure if st.joe guy has been to it,actually it's white knuckle driving anywhere on st.joe.The lake is plum full of fish though.

Am I missing something? The OP asked about Â“drive toÂ” camps. I know Winoga and Old Post are not drive-to camps where you park next to the cabin. They're boat-in camps. And I'm not sure Camp St. Joseph is a traditional drive-to camp either. May sound like I'm picky, but there is a difference and depending on one's situation it could be a big deal. Suppose you got a call after dark and had to run home. At a drive-to camp, no problem just jump in your truck and head south. If you boated in it could be a big problem in the dark, in the wind or in the storm. As often said, the devil is in the details.
smith camps Lake of the woods gets my vote. https://www.smithcamps.com/
Your correct old timer,old post n camp st.joe are park n boat out there,getting out of there in the dark probably not wise.

In the vermilion bay area you have a bunch of great camps that are DRIVE IN.Excluding Eagle and Lac Suel due to there size but if you go to these big lakes you don't have to go far to get great fishing.Most fisherman just go to far.So I'll mention Onaway Lodge and and Little Vermilion Lodge anyways.Kc,s camp on the Indian Lake chain is a great place with good fishing and awesome beach if you bring kids.You know iam going to say Clark's on Cedar.lol.but there's also Cedar Lake camp,Cedar Lake Lodge,Cedar Point Lodge and Keystone.All this camps are great for a weeks stay and not that expensive in in my view some of the most consistent fishing you can ask for.Smaller Lake with plenty of get out of the wind places.Cedar Lake Lodge is a boat in.
Big North....Just South of Minaki on the Winnipeg River.
